content: The Act titled "Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998" revises limits on mental health benefits. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 expand coverage under ERISA for group health plans and insurance to include treatment limitations and financial requirements for mental health benefits. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 require group health plans to provide equal coverage for mental health benefits without imposing treatment limitations or financial requirements that are not imposed on medical and surgical benefits in comparable settings. This does not prevent plans from negotiating separate reimbursement rates and service delivery systems for different benefits. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 allow group health plans to negotiate separate reimbursement rates and service delivery systems for different benefits, while also requiring equal coverage for mental health benefits without imposing treatment limitations or financial requirements not imposed on medical and surgical benefits. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 require group health plans to provide equal coverage for mental health benefits without treatment limits. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 mandate equal coverage for mental health benefits without treatment limits, including financial requirements like copayments and deductibles. The amendments also eliminate cost exemptions previously allowed. The Mental Health and Substance Abuse Parity Amendments of 1998 eliminate cost exemptions, treatment limitations, and sunset provisions in the coverage of mental health benefits under group health plans.
